A: 14. Penny had #60.00. She spent #20.00 and #40.00. How much has she left? (a) 10.00 (b) 20.00 (c) 0.00
15. Six children have two copybooks each. How many copybooks is that in total? (a) 26 (b) 12 (c) 13
16. There are 8 sausages in a packet. How many in three packets? (a) 20 (b) 22 (c) 24
17. Molly woke up at 8:35 and had breakfast 10 minutes later. What time was that? (a) 9:35 (b) 8:45 (c) 8:25
18. 23 pupils were in the bus. 3 got off, and then 4 got off. How many were left? (a) 21 (b) 19 (c) 16
19. Mr. Christopher divided 18 pupils into 3 groups. How many were in each group? (a) 8 (b) 6 (c) 7
20. There are 28, 31 and 30 days in three months. How many days altogether? (a) 87 (b) 89 (c) 88
23. How many marbles were neither yellow nor green? (a) 4 (b) 9 (c) Not enough information
24. One marble was black and the rest were blue. How many were blue? (a) 15 (b) 3 (c) Not enough information
29. By how much is 46 greater than 29? (a) 13 (b) 17 (c) 23
30. A carpenter is making 8 chairs. How many legs will he need to make? (a) 12 (b) 24 (c) 32
B: 6. A decade is a period of _________ years.
C: 1. Explain the concept of odd and even numbers. Provide examples of each.
2. Describe different types of geometric shapes and their properties.
3. Explain the relationship between addition and subtraction. How are they related?
4. What is the importance of mathematics in everyday life? Give specific examples.
5. Explain the order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS) in mathematical expressions with examples.
6. Discuss the concept of fractions and their applications in real-world scenarios.
7. What are the different units of measurement for length, weight, and volume? Explain with examples.
8. Explain the concept of time and how it is measured. Include units like seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months and years.
9. What are the different types of angles? Explain with examples.
